articles.headline: Boeing Fix for Battery Is Approved by F.A.A.
articles.snippet: The decision, which came three months after the passenger jets were grounded, could allow the planes to return to service in weeks.
articles.abstract: The decision, which came three months after the passenger jets were grounded, could allow the planes to return to service in weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boeing’s 787s could be flying again within weeks, a major milestone for the innovative passenger jets that have been grounded since January because of battery problems.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: The Case of H.P.’s Obstinate Director
articles.snippet: It took the combined efforts of Hewlett-Packard’s chief executive, other board members and the company’s largest shareholder to get Raymond Lane to give up his role as H.P.’s chairman.
articles.abstract: It took the combined efforts of Hewlett-Packard’s chief executive, other board members and the company’s largest shareholder to get Raymond Lane to give up his role as H.P.’s chairman.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Hewlett-Packard announced earlier this month that two directors were resigning and that Raymond Lane was giving up his title of chairman, the company portrayed the moves as selfless and purely voluntary.

articles.headline: Budget Negotiating Chip Has Big Downside for Old and Poor
articles.snippet: Many of those who would be affected by President Obama’s Social Security proposal face higher health costs and have little hope of working again.
articles.abstract: Many of those who would be affected by President Obama’s Social Security proposal face higher health costs and have little hope of working again.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama has put Social Security on the table in an attempt to reach a bipartisan agreement on the federal budget deficit, a move that would hit the program’s beneficiaries when they are at their most vulnerable.

articles.headline: Part-Time Work Becomes Full-Time Wait for Better Job
articles.snippet: Despite strong recent job growth, 7.6 million Americans who want to work more hours have been stuck in part-time jobs.
articles.abstract: Despite strong recent job growth, 7.6 million Americans who want to work more hours have been stuck in part-time jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy has generated 30 straight months of job growth. But for millions of people looking for more work and greater income, that improvement provides little solace.

articles.headline: Bombing Inquiry Turns to Motive and Russian Trip
articles.snippet: With one suspect dead and the other lying wounded in a hospital, the investigation into the Boston bombings turned to the men’s motives, and to a trip one of them took to Chechnya and Dagestan.
articles.abstract: With one suspect dead and the other lying wounded in a hospital, the investigation into the Boston bombings turned to the men’s motives, and to a trip one of them took to Chechnya and Dagestan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With one suspect dead and the other captured and lying grievously wounded in a hospital, the investigation into the Boston Marathon bombings turned on Saturday to questions about the men’s motives, and to the significance of an overseas trip one of them took last year.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Michael S. Schmidt and Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Suspects With Foot in 2 Worlds, Perhaps Echoing Plots of Past
articles.snippet: The case of the Boston suspects recalls that of other young men who, caught between life in America and loyalty to fellow Muslims in a distant homeland, turned to violence.
articles.abstract: The case of the Boston suspects recalls that of other young men who, caught between life in America and loyalty to fellow Muslims in a distant homeland, turned to violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, when Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was assigned by his high school English teacher to write an essay on something he felt passionate about, he chose the troubled land of his ancestors: Chechnya. He wrote to Brian Glyn Williams, a professor at the University of Massachusetts at Dartmouth.

articles.headline: Daring to Knock on the Boardroom Door
articles.snippet: A mutual fund manager is posing a challenge to the richly paid directors of Occidental Petroleum.
articles.abstract: A mutual fund manager is posing a challenge to the richly paid directors of Occidental Petroleum.
articles.lead_paragraph: STEVEN ROMICK didn’t set out to be a shareholder activist. As managing partner of First Pacific Advisors and overseer of the $11 billion FPA Crescent fund, Mr. Romick has more than enough on his plate. Keeping a low profile is usually fine with him.

articles.headline: Thrown for a Curve in Rhode Island
articles.snippet: The baseball star Curt Schilling dazzled a state government with his video-game business plan. But two years later, it was game over.
articles.abstract: The baseball star Curt Schilling dazzled a state government with his video-game business plan. But two years later, it was game over.
articles.lead_paragraph: You have to imagine what it was like being Don Carcieri in the harsh winter of 2010. As Rhode Island’s governor, a Republican in an overwhelmingly Democratic state, he had come into office seven years earlier as a business executive turned politician, vowing to retool the state’s corroded economy.

articles.headline: Conservative Koch Brothers Turning Focus to Newspapers
articles.snippet: Charles and David Koch, the billionaire industrialists and supporters of libertarian causes, are exploring a bid to buy the Tribune Company’s eight regional newspapers.
articles.abstract: Charles and David Koch, the billionaire industrialists and supporters of libertarian causes, are exploring a bid to buy the Tribune Company’s eight regional newspapers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Charles and David Koch, the billionaire industrialists and supporters of libertarian causes, held a seminar of like-minded, wealthy political donors at the St. Regis Resort in Aspen, Colo. They laid out a three-pronged, 10-year strategy to shift the country toward a smaller government with less regulation and taxes.

articles.headline: Rewinding History, Bush Museum Lets You Decide
articles.snippet: Visitors to an interactive theater at the George W. Bush Presidential Library and Museum will be presented with the stark choices that confronted the nation’s 43rd president.
articles.abstract: Visitors to an interactive theater at the George W. Bush Presidential Library and Museum will be presented with the stark choices that confronted the nation’s 43rd president.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNIVERSITY PARK, Tex. — More than four years after leaving office, former President George W. Bush has a question for America: So what would you have done?

articles.headline: Danes Rethink a Welfare State Ample to a Fault
articles.snippet: With little fuss or political protest — or notice abroad — Denmark has been at work overhauling entitlements, trying to prod Danes into working more, longer or both.
articles.abstract: With little fuss or political protest — or notice abroad — Denmark has been at work overhauling entitlements, trying to prod Danes into working more, longer or both.
articles.lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — It began as a stunt intended to prove that hardship and poverty still existed in this small, wealthy country, but it backfired badly. Visit a single mother of two on welfare, a liberal member of Parliament goaded a skeptical political opponent, see for yourself how hard it is.

articles.headline: A Comedy Show That Comes via a Hashtag
articles.snippet: Comedy Central will use Twitter to host a comedy festival. The partnership between the two companies represents the evolving relationship between television and social media.
articles.abstract: Comedy Central will use Twitter to host a comedy festival. The partnership between the two companies represents the evolving relationship between television and social media.
articles.lead_paragraph: Next week, Comedy Central will host a five-day comedy festival that includes a lineup of legends like Mel Brooks and Carl Reiner alongside popular young comics like Amy Schumer and the director Paul Feig.

articles.headline: The Pressure to Be the TV News Leader Tarnishes a Big Brand
articles.snippet: When big news breaks, a common impulse is to turn to CNN, but the network suffers from self-inflicted damage.
articles.abstract: When big news breaks, a common impulse is to turn to CNN, but the network suffers from self-inflicted damage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like a lot of Americans, when I woke up on Friday morning and found out there was a manhunt in the Boston area for the remaining suspect in Monday’s bombing at the marathon, I turned on CNN.

articles.headline: Sports Goggles Can Provide Vital Data and Distraction
articles.snippet: Several companies produce sports eyewear that provides data, including speed and altitude, heart rate and time per mile, but critics say the devices create a distraction that could be dangerous.
articles.abstract: Several companies produce sports eyewear that provides data, including speed and altitude, heart rate and time per mile, but critics say the devices create a distraction that could be dangerous.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oakley, the eyewear company, makes a $600 ski goggle that comes with a warning in the package: Do not operate product while skiing.

articles.headline: In Europe, Paid Permits for Pollution Are Fizzling
articles.snippet: The low price of carbon credits means the market is not doing its job: pushing polluters to reduce carbon emissions, which most climate scientists believe contribute to global warming.
articles.abstract: The low price of carbon credits means the market is not doing its job: pushing polluters to reduce carbon emissions, which most climate scientists believe contribute to global warming.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — On a showery afternoon last week in West London, a ripple of enthusiasm went through the trading floor of CF Partners, a privately owned financial company. The price of carbon allowances, shown in green lights on a board hanging from the ceiling, was creeping up toward three euros.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Mark Scott

articles.headline: With Tablets, Businesses Ring Up at More Fanciful Cash Registers
articles.snippet: With the advent of the tablet, the payment system is coming unmoored from the cash register bulwark. So far the change has occurred mostly in small businesses.
articles.abstract: With the advent of the tablet, the payment system is coming unmoored from the cash register bulwark. So far the change has occurred mostly in small businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The humble cash register, a device that seems sprung from the imagination of an accountant, has become the darling of designers, adding a dash of style to the most ordinary daily transactions.

articles.headline: Activist’s Death in Egypt Spurs Charges of Police Abuse
articles.snippet: The death of Mohamed el-Gindy has underscored one of the most vexing challenges facing the new government: how to tame Egypt’s unaccountable and despised security forces.
articles.abstract: The death of Mohamed el-Gindy has underscored one of the most vexing challenges facing the new government: how to tame Egypt’s unaccountable and despised security forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Mohamed el-Gindy spent three days in violent protests around Tahrir Square. In a television interview, he promised a backlash if the new Islamist government tried to recreate the Egyptian police state.

articles.headline: Web Helps Musicians Sell Shares of Royalties
articles.snippet: Web sites like the Royalty Exchange allows musicians to sell parts of their royalty income to investors and define which rights to sell and which to retain.
articles.abstract: Web sites like the Royalty Exchange allows musicians to sell parts of their royalty income to investors and define which rights to sell and which to retain.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a songwriter and producer for stars like Natalie Cole, Aretha Franklin and Whitney Houston, Preston Glass receives a comfortable stream of music royalties. But when he needed to make a substantial investment to embark on the next phase of his career — as a performing artist in his own right — he had few options to raise the money, he said.

articles.headline: Investigators Dig for Roots of Bomb Suspects’ Radicalization
articles.snippet: The authorities have grown increasingly certain that the two men suspected in the Boston Marathon bombings acted alone and were most likely planning to put a small arsenal to use in additional attacks.
articles.abstract: The authorities have grown increasingly certain that the two men suspected in the Boston Marathon bombings acted alone and were most likely planning to put a small arsenal to use in additional attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The two men suspected in the Boston Marathon bombings were armed with a small arsenal of guns, ammunition and explosives when they first confronted the police early Friday, and were most likely planning more attacks, the authorities said Sunday.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Search for Home Led Suspect to Land Marred by Strife
articles.snippet: Tamerlan Tsarnaev, one of the suspects in the Boston bombings, found comfort in Dagestan, a region in the North Caucasus that is the center of violent Islamic insurgency in Russia.
articles.abstract: Tamerlan Tsarnaev, one of the suspects in the Boston bombings, found comfort in Dagestan, a region in the North Caucasus that is the center of violent Islamic insurgency in Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAKHACHKALA, Russia — Tamerlan Tsarnaev had already found religion by the time he landed in Dagestan, a combustible region in the North Caucasus that has become the epicenter of a violent Islamic insurgency in Russia and a hub of jihadist recruitment. What he seemed to be yearning for was a home.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Andrew Roth

articles.headline: U.S. Box Office Heroes Proving Mortal in China
articles.snippet: Hollywood blockbusters appeared poised last year to take over China’s box office, but something unexpected happened on the way to the bank: demand tapered off sharply.
articles.abstract: Hollywood blockbusters appeared poised last year to take over China’s box office, but something unexpected happened on the way to the bank: demand tapered off sharply.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood’s global business strategy, which counts on huge ticket sales in China for high-budget fantasies in 3-D and large-screen Imax formats, is coming unhinged.

articles.headline: Restyled as Real Estate Trusts, Varied Businesses Avoid Taxes
articles.snippet: Redefining companies as real estate investment trusts can nearly — even completely — eliminate federal taxes.
articles.abstract: Redefining companies as real estate investment trusts can nearly — even completely — eliminate federal taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: A small but growing number of American corporations, operating in businesses as diverse as private prisons, billboards and casinos, are making an aggressive move to reduce — or even eliminate — their federal tax bills.

articles.headline: Boston Suspect Is Charged and Could Face the Death Penalty
articles.snippet: The surviving suspect in the marathon bombings, who officials said admitted to a role in the attacks, was charged with using a weapon of mass destruction.
articles.abstract: The surviving suspect in the marathon bombings, who officials said admitted to a role in the attacks, was charged with using a weapon of mass destruction.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Lying grievously wounded in a hospital bed, the surviving suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings admitted on Sunday to playing a role in the attacks, said law enforcement officials, and on Monday he was charged with using a weapon of mass destruction that resulted in three deaths and more than 170 injuries.
articles.byline: By Katharine Q. Seelye, Michael S. Schmidt and William K. Rashbaum
